title: 2005 Porsche Carrera GT
description: This 2005 Porsche Carrera GT is one of 1,270 examples built during a four-year production run and now has 11k miles. The car spent time in Michigan and Ontario before being acquired by the current owner in 2019, and work in 2025 involved replacing the clutch assembly, camshafts, tires, and trailing arms as well as installing Öhlins TTX coilovers. It is finished in GT Silver Metallic over Terracotta leather and is powered by a 5.7-liter V10 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle. Features include XT-sized seats, 19" and 20" center-lock alloy wheels, ceramic composite brakes, an electronically actuated rear spoiler, removable roof panels, xenon headlights, air conditioning, and a Porsche Online Pro CD stereo. This Type 980 is now offered in Scottsdale, Arizona on dealer consignment with a set of Terracotta leather fitted luggage, a Porsche Classic Technical Certificate, the owner's manual, service records, and a clean Montana title.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Bid for the chance to own a 2005 Porsche Carrera GT at auction with Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online. Lot #188,181.
text: This 2005 Porsche Carrera GT is one of 1,270 examples built during a four-year production run and now has 11k miles. The car spent time in Michigan and Ontario before being acquired by the current owner in 2019, and work in 2025 involved replacing the clutch assembly, camshafts, tires, and trailing arms as well as installing Öhlins TTX coilovers. It is finished in GT Silver Metallic over Terracotta leather and is powered by a 5.7-liter V10 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle. Features include XT-sized seats, 19″ and 20″ center-lock alloy wheels, ceramic composite brakes, an electronically actuated rear spoiler, removable roof panels, xenon headlights, air conditioning, and a Porsche Online Pro CD stereo. This Type 980 is now offered in Scottsdale, Arizona on dealer consignment with a set of Terracotta leather fitted luggage, a Porsche Classic Technical Certificate, the owner’s manual, service records, and a clean Montana title. The Carrera GT concept car first appeared at the 2000 Paris Motor Show as an offshoot of the late-1990s LMP2000 development prototype that never came to fruition. The model entered production in 2003 with construction incorporating a carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic monocoque and subframe built by ATR Group in Italy. The carbon-fiber body panels on this example are finished in GT Silver Metallic (M7Z) with matching removable roof panels. Aerodynamic elements include an undertray, a rear diffuser, and an electronically actuated rear spoiler that can also be deployed using a button on the center console. The forged magnesium wheels measure 19×9.5” up front and 20×12.5” at the rear and are secured by center-lock nuts that are color-coded in reference to thread direction. Stopping power is provided by cross-drilled 15” ceramic composite brake rotors with yellow six-piston monobloc aluminum calipers at each corner. Work completed by Porsche of Colorado Springs in February 2025 involved replacing the front and rear trailing arm assemblies under warranty due to manufacturer recall in addition to flushing the brake fluid and installing Öhlins TTX coilovers and replacement Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2 tires all around. The removed factory shocks accompany the car. The interior features XT-sized racing-style seats with carbon-fiber and Kevlar shells trimmed in Terracotta leather along with a matching dashboard, center console, door A-pillars, and door caps. The Carrera GT features magnesium, carbon-fiber, and aluminum interior trim, and additional equipment includes one-touch power windows, air conditioning, heated power-adjustable side mirrors, and a Porsche Online Pro CD stereo. The high-mounted shifter is topped with a laminated beechwood knob in homage to the balsa units that appeared in Porsche 917 race cars. The serialization ahead of the shifter denotes this chassis as #613. The leather-wrapped airbag steering wheel frames a central tachometer with an 8,400-rpm redline as well as a 235-mph speedometer and auxiliary gauges. The digital odometer indicates 11k miles, approximately 1k of which were added under current ownership. The mid-mounted 5.7-liter M80/01 V10 is liquid-cooled and features dual overhead camshafts on each cylinder bank, titanium connecting rods, dry-sump lubrication, and Bosch Motronic ME7 engine management. It produced 605 horsepower at 8,000-rpm and 435 lb-ft of torque at 5,750-rpm when new. Power is routed to the rear wheels via a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. Including the aforementioned work on the suspension, total service completed by Porsche of Colorado Springs in February 2025 totaled over $121k and is detailed on invoices provided in the gallery. It involved a valve adjustment, engine oil and transmission fluid changes, and replacement of the following components: Camshafts Clutch assembly Clutch release module Ignition coils Spark plugs Water pump belt Power steering belt Cylinder head coolant line Tappets Tensioner rollers Engine & cabin air filters Various seals, O-rings, and more A set of Terracotta leather fitted luggage is included in the sale. The Porsche Classic Technical Certificate was issued in February 2025 and lists the factory colors and equipment. Technical check results viewable in the gallery detail the engine and gearbox stampings. The Carfax report shows no accidents or other damage. You are not connected to real-time updates. html:
This 2005 Porsche Carrera GT is one of 1,270 examples built during a four-year production run and now has 11k miles. The car spent time in Michigan and Ontario before being acquired by the current owner in 2019, and work in 2025 involved replacing the clutch assembly, camshafts, tires, and trailing arms as well as installing Öhlins TTX coilovers. It is finished in GT Silver Metallic over Terracotta leather and is powered by a 5.7-liter V10 paired with a six-speed manual transaxle. Features include XT-sized seats, 19″ and 20″ center-lock alloy wheels, ceramic composite brakes, an electronically actuated rear spoiler, removable roof panels, xenon headlights, air conditioning, and a Porsche Online Pro CD stereo. This Type 980 is now offered in Scottsdale, Arizona on dealer consignment with a set of Terracotta leather fitted luggage, a Porsche Classic Technical Certificate, the owner’s manual, service records, and a clean Montana title.

The Carrera GT concept car first appeared at the 2000 Paris Motor Show as an offshoot of the late-1990s LMP2000 development prototype that never came to fruition. The model entered production in 2003 with construction incorporating a carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic monocoque and subframe built by ATR Group in Italy.

The carbon-fiber body panels on this example are finished in GT Silver Metallic (M7Z) with matching removable roof panels. Aerodynamic elements include an undertray, a rear diffuser, and an electronically actuated rear spoiler that can also be deployed using a button on the center console.

The forged magnesium wheels measure 19×9.5” up front and 20×12.5” at the rear and are secured by center-lock nuts that are color-coded in reference to thread direction. Stopping power is provided by cross-drilled 15” ceramic composite brake rotors with yellow six-piston monobloc aluminum calipers at each corner. Work completed by Porsche of Colorado Springs in February 2025 involved replacing the front and rear trailing arm assemblies under warranty due to manufacturer recall in addition to flushing the brake fluid and installing Öhlins TTX coilovers and replacement Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2 tires all around. The removed factory shocks accompany the car.

The interior features XT-sized racing-style seats with carbon-fiber and Kevlar shells trimmed in Terracotta leather along with a matching dashboard, center console, door A-pillars, and door caps. The Carrera GT features magnesium, carbon-fiber, and aluminum interior trim, and additional equipment includes one-touch power windows, air conditioning, heated power-adjustable side mirrors, and a Porsche Online Pro CD stereo. The high-mounted shifter is topped with a laminated beechwood knob in homage to the balsa units that appeared in Porsche 917 race cars.

The serialization ahead of the shifter denotes this chassis as #613.

The leather-wrapped airbag steering wheel frames a central tachometer with an 8,400-rpm redline as well as a 235-mph speedometer and auxiliary gauges. The digital odometer indicates 11k miles, approximately 1k of which were added under current ownership.

The mid-mounted 5.7-liter M80/01 V10 is liquid-cooled and features dual overhead camshafts on each cylinder bank, titanium connecting rods, dry-sump lubrication, and Bosch Motronic ME7 engine management. It produced 605 horsepower at 8,000-rpm and 435 lb-ft of torque at 5,750-rpm when new. Power is routed to the rear wheels via a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. Including the aforementioned work on the suspension, total service completed by Porsche of Colorado Springs in February 2025 totaled over $121k and is detailed on invoices provided in the gallery. It involved a valve adjustment, engine oil and transmission fluid changes, and replacement of the following components:

  • Camshafts
  • Clutch assembly
  • Clutch release module
  • Ignition coils
  • Spark plugs
  • Water pump belt
  • Power steering belt
  • Cylinder head coolant line
  • Tappets
  • Tensioner rollers
  • Engine & cabin air filters
  • Various seals, O-rings, and more

A set of Terracotta leather fitted luggage is included in the sale.

The Porsche Classic Technical Certificate was issued in February 2025 and lists the factory colors and equipment. Technical check results viewable in the gallery detail the engine and gearbox stampings.

The Carfax report shows no accidents or other damage.
